description: {"blocks":[{"key":"aqp7e","text":"Background: Over the past two decades, transcriptional profiling has become an increasingly common tool for investigating the effects of diseases and experimental manipulations on the nervous system. Within transcriptional profiling experiments, microarray or sequencing technologies are used to measure the relative amount of RNA transcript for each of the thousands of genes expressed in a sample. The primary objective of these experiments is to identify genes that are differentially expressed in response to conditions of interest. However, transcriptional profiling experiments have traditionally been conducted with small sample sizes due to expense (e.g., n=3-10/group), resulting in low statistical power. Due to low power, these experiments are prone to capturing large technical artifacts and false positives rather than smaller biological effects of interest.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1etn8","text":"Methods: To address this issue, we developed a 10-week summer research program (The Brain Data Alchemy Project) that guides participants through the process of performing a meta-analysis of differential expression effect sizes (Log2 Fold Change or Log2FC) extracted from publicly available transcriptional profiling datasets. To conduct our meta-analyses, we leverage the efforts of the Gemma project, which has curated, preprocessed, and re-analyzed over 19,000 publicly available datasets (https://gemma.msl.ubc.ca/home.html). Participants learn the fundamental principles of systematic review and R programming to conduct the dataset search, result extraction, and whole transcriptome meta-analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9},{"style":"italic","offset":80,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"58vq4","text":"Version Information: This protocol outlines the methods used during the second pilot year of the program in 2023. These methods differ from the 2022 methods (dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.j8nlk84jxl5r/v1): The 2023 project methods import the preprocessed gene expression data and metadata from Gemma, whereas the 2022 project methods import the differential expression results.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":20},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":158,"length":48}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":158,"length":48}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2C0637B9609D11EFAC0E0A58A9FEAC02","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.j8nlk84jxl5r/v1"}}}}
disclaimer: {"blocks":[{"key":"h0md","text":"This protocol provides meta-analysis guidelines and sample code, but not a full reproducible analysis pipeline and coding environment. It was meant to be adapted to the needs of each individual project.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"eht65","text":"Any questions regarding this protocol should be directed to Dr. Megan Hagenauer (University of Michigan: hagenaue@umich.edu).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"k7k3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"udbm","text":"This protocol outlines the meta-analysis methods recommended to participants within the Brain Data Alchemy Program during the second pilot year of the program (2023). These methods were updated for later years - for updates, see the associated forks for this protocol and for the protocol from the first pilot year of the program (2022: dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.j8nlk84jxl5r/v1).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":337,"length":48}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"84D659A76ED511EFA6C70A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.j8nlk84jxl5r/v1"}}}}

","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7s1ap","text":"Full guidelines about how to conduct a systematic meta-analysis can be found here:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":33,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fm7b7","text":"https://www.prisma-statement.org/","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"AC29284F283511EF9EFE0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.prisma-statement.org"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"1":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Moher D, Liberati A, Tetzlaff J, Altman DG, PRISMA Group","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1248134400,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.b2535","guid":"A2BBDCD7902B4F6F8863D8EE181AAC6E","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"Preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses: the PRISMA statement."}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Liberati A, Altman DG, Tetzlaff J, Mulrow C, Gøtzsche PC, Ioannidis JP, Clarke M, Devereaux PJ, Kleijnen J, Moher D","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1248134400,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.b2700","guid":"152CC36DE9364588B7CF7B4D948ACCC3","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"The PRISMA statement for reporting systematic reviews and meta-analyses of studies that evaluate healthcare interventions: explanation and elaboration."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4de1p","text":"Pre-specify the search terms for your topic.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d6ej8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dfm85","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f476g","text":"The search terms should be thoroughly brainstormed to catch any dataset related to the meta-analysis topic. e.g., ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"957ra","text":"Topic","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"18s4v","text":"Synonyms for Topic","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4vulq","text":"Abbreviations for Topic","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2oa0o","text":"Subtypes of Topic","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c51tl","text":"Umbrella Categories for Topic","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3gn0b","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f754k","text":"Since this is a critical step, feedback on search terms is important. For the 2023 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, these terms were reviewed by the mentor and whole cohort.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7tvb6","text":"The information source will be the same for all meta-analyses: The Gemma Database.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8mi4k","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bot00","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"742jo","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"73l56","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rmkj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1deve","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e6lf","text":"We will be leveraging the efforts of the Gemma project to curate, preprocess, and re-analyze publicly-available transcriptional profiling datasets:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":34,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"27ca3","text":"https://gemma.msl.ubc.ca/home.html","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"67aql","text":"The Gemma database contains \u003e19,000 re-analyzed transcriptional profiling datasets. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d898","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"da2te","text":"Gemma performs the following data preprocessing and analysis steps: ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"lslr","text":"1) Probe alignment or read mapping is redone whenever a new genome assembly is available. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b7qn6","text":"2) Identification and removal of outlier samples. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"faaha","text":"3) Filtering out genes (rows) with minimal variance (either zero variance or \u003c70% distinct values). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b7lkc","text":"4) Batch correction: When confounded, batches are split into separate analyses. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4tms8","text":"5) Manual curation of common issues. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e9sjc","text":"6) Differential expression output from omnibus (full dataset) tests examining the effects of the primary variables of interest as well as individual statistical contrasts.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"arm8f","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dmr6j","text":"For the current (2023) version of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, we will only be directly building upon some of Gemma's analysis efforts (steps #1, #5), but will be reapplying analysis methods that are similar to those used by Gemma for steps #2-4 \u0026 #6.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"312C1CF5283611EF9EFE0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://gemma.msl.ubc.ca/home.html"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"1":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Zoubarev A, Hamer KM, Keshav KD, McCarthy EL, Santos JR, Van Rossum T, McDonald C, Hall A, Wan X, Lim R, Gillis J, Pavlidis P","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1346457600,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/bts430","guid":"5F05E153D20A41699901EF3FFD65D8CD","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"Gemma: a resource for the reuse, sharing and meta-analysis of expression profiling data."}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Lim N, Tesar S, Belmadani M, Poirier-Morency G, Mancarci BO, Sicherman J, Jacobson M, Leong J, Tan P, Pavlidis P","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1613606400,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1093/database/baab006","guid":"B54826386D1D4C3C93B49BBF392770B4","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"Curation of over 10 000 transcriptomic studies to enable data reuse."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fqf46","text":"The scope of our meta-analysis search is pre-specified below. The scope will be the same for each meta-analysis conducted using the Brain Data Alchemy analysis pipeline.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c44b9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4rlg6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4p0o3","text":"For our meta-analysis, we will only be considering:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bhhf9","text":"1) Publicly-available transcriptional profiling datasets (gene expression microarray or RNA-Sequencing) from laboratory rodents (rats, mice). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2bspk","text":"2) We will only use datasets that profiled RNA extracted from bulk tissue dissections (i.e., not from a particular cell type or small tissue subregion).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9naj4","text":"3) We will only use datasets that profiled either the full transcriptome or a large representation of the full transcriptome. We will not use datasets targeted at a particular subpopulation of transcripts (e.g., Chip-Seq, miRNA, TRAP-Seq, etc).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dnpfr","text":"Choose your meta-analysis topic and primary research question.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78j0i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7i0dc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3s624","text":"Not all topics or research questions have been studied extensively using brain transcriptional profiling data. At this point, before pursuing the meta-analysis further, it would be helpful to have a second researcher who is not directly involved in the project (e.g., research mentor) quickly double-check whether there appears to be datasets in the Gemma database related to the chosen topic. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bt74e","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c4bha","text":"This quick, initial review should only use a handful of the most basic search terms for the topic. It is often advisable to wait to specify the tissue of interest (e.g., brain region) until later after you have determined how many the available datasets will survive the initial inclusion/exclusion criteria (protocol section 6). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"470ra","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"aqbgc","text":"The 2023 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project chose to examine the effects of chronic pain, early life stress, chronic stress, and individual factors modulating chronic stress responses (sex, stress susceptibility vs. stress resilience).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

It is likely to work using other versions.\n\n","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"software","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"id":1908,"link":"http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/devtools/index.html","name":"R Package devtools","os_name":"","os_version":"","repository":"http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/devtools/index.html","version":"","developer":"Wickham, Hester, Chan, and Bryan","can_edit":0,"guid":"FF169FFF5FF311EF97AD0A58A9FEAC02"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"co42e","text":"Use the function search_datasets() to locate transcriptional profiling datasets within the Gemma database that contain your prespecified keywords. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":17,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"flegk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"121fu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2inv3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5tken","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R Code: Searching for Gemma Datasets by Keyword","description":"Example R code: Identifying datasets from mice and rats with our search terms","guid":"51A902DF29B111EF84A60A58A9FEAC02","name":"#Identifying datasets that fit our search terms in mice:

#First, determine how many datasets from mice fit our search:

result <- gemma.R ::search_datasets(SearchTerms, taxon = 'mouse',limit = 1) 

print(attributes(result)$totalElements)
#[1]  111
#There are 111 datasets that fit this search.

#Gemma.R can only download 100 dataset metadata records at a time, so if we have more than 100 results, we will need to perform the search interatively, with the number of iterations determined by the total number of datasets divided by 100:

SearchIterations<-floor(attributes(result)$totalElements/100)

#We can run the search for the first 100 records using the basic syntax:

TempResult<-gemma.R ::search_datasets(SearchTerms, taxon = 'mouse',limit = 100) 

#Then we run a loop to gather the next sets of 100 records, and add those records into the same dataframe as additional rows:

for(i in c(1:SearchIterations)){
  TempResult<-rbind.data.frame(TempResult,(gemma.R ::search_datasets(SearchTerms, taxon = 'mouse',limit = 100, offset=i*100)))
}

#I recommend renaming the object afterwards to make it easier to keep track of things later:
results_Stress_Hippocampus_Mice<-TempResult

#Cleaning up our workspace of objects that aren't needed anymore:
rm(result, TempResult, SearchIterations)

############

#Identifying datasets with our search terms in rats:

result <- gemma.R ::search_datasets(SearchTerms, taxon = 'rat',limit = 1) 

print(attributes(result)$totalElements)
#[1] 36
#There are less than 100 datasets that fit this search, so we do not need to iterate our search.

TempResult<-gemma.R ::search_datasets(SearchTerms, taxon = 'rat',limit = 100) 

#I renamed the object containing all of the rat datasets to make it easier to keep track of later:
results_Stress_Hippocampus_Rat<-TempResult

#Cleaning up our workspace of objects that aren't needed anymore:
rm(result, TempResult, SearchIterations)","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":17,"offset":28,"style":"italic"}],"key":"dd72o","text":"- The first argument in the search_datasets() function is your search term syntax. The full syntax for the search terms will need to be placed in quotations as if it were a single string value.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"820al","text":"- The argument "taxon" allows you to filter by species.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1ejhn","text":"- Gemma.R can't extract more than 100 records at a time (the "limit")","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"32jmn","text":"- If we have more than 100 results, we will need to perform the search interatively, with the number of iterations determined by the total number of datasets divided by 100.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"atddu","text":"-If we run the search for the first 100 records using the basic syntax, we can then run a for loop to gather the next sets of 100 records, and add those records into the same data frame as additional rows.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cskjp","text":"Compile the metadata records from these identified datasets into a single data frame.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ars3a","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"etdfa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Combining search results into a single data frame","description":"","guid":"EE06D7EE2A7C11EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"combined\u003c-rbind.data.frame(results_Stress_Hippocampus_Mice, results_Stress_Hippocampus_Rat)\n","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dti9e","text":"Eliminate any duplicated records in the data frame.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ampnt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eg0te","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Removing duplicated metadata records","description":"","guid":"28C55AB12A7D11EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"unique_combined\u003c- unique(combined)","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

steps.section: Specification of Tissue of Interest (If Not Pre-Specified)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4k1gg","text":"If a particular tissue or brain region of interest (ROI) had not been pre-specified in the search criteria, the research question should now be narrowed to a particular tissue or brain ROI based on dataset availability, and the dataset records filtered accordingly. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"181i5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3ti8b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"592nr","text":"At this point, since the titles and abstracts for the datasets have already been viewed, it is important to run decisions about tissue/ROI definition past a second researcher who is less invested in the project (e.g., a research mentor) to guard against bias. These decisions may include whether to include datasets from samples that only focus on a subregion of the larger ROI, or whether to include tissue cultures as well as fresh-collected tissue.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"585t8","text":"This is a critical step. Following this initial filtering by the individual experimenter, all inclusion/exclusion choices should be reviewed and approved by a second researcher (such as a research mentor). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6mkfp","text":"The titles, abstracts, and metadata for the datasets should then be scanned to determine which datasets should be excluded based on our pre-specified criteria. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56gt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bi74v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7hr2t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"79eul","text":"Pre-specified exclusion criteria:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fk2jq","text":"1) Brain tissue was not collected. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ai4ep","text":"2) The experimental manipulation was unrelated to the meta-analysis topic. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"92ek7","text":"3) The brain tissue used in the experiment was not from a bulk dissection, and instead represented a particular cell type or small subregion. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"efv27","text":"4) The experiment targeted a particular subpopulation of transcripts (e.g., Chip-Seq, miRNA, TRAP-Seq, etc.).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c0hkr","text":"5) The experiment used subjects from a developmental stage other than the timeframe of interest.\n6) The metadata record on Gemma has critical issues, including duplication/overlap with another record or critical missing information (minimal methodological information due to no associated publication and a minimalist metadata record).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Secondary Dataset Filtering Using Detailed Methodological Review
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"epg8d","text":"The remaining dataset metadata records should now be subjected to a detailed review of accompanying experimental methods and available file formats. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5stfi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a59kf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b4206","text":"For this level of filtering, the publications associated with the datasets need to be referenced in addition to the metadata available on Gemma. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"als9l","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3qghb","text":"Only the methodological information in the publication and Gemma record should be used to determine study/dataset inclusion/exclusion, because we want our inclusion/exclusion criteria to be independent of the results reported in the original publication as much as possible. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8dsau","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f38ua","text":"Ideally, this would mean that only the methods section of the publication (or supplementary methods) would be read in depth. However, sometimes it is necessary to reference other sections of the paper in order to interpret or locate methodological information. For example, it may be necessary to read the introduction to understand the terminology and abbreviations used in the paper. Likewise, sometimes the experimental design will be overviewed in a figure, or final quality control decisions (and final sample sizes) discussed at the beginning of the results section or in the figure legends. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9iba","text":"When reviewing the methodological information in the publications and metadata for the datasets, studies should be excluded using pre-specified inclusion/exclusion criteria. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cth7d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f8mjq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8et3f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"18usd","text":"Pre-specified inclusion/exclusion criteria:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7084s","text":"1) The study was retracted. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4iua2","text":"2) The experimental design was confounded or lacked a proper control group for the experimental manipulation of interest.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7895o","text":"3) The subjects or protocol used in the study were dramatically different from all other included datasets.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6rje5","text":"Depending on the research topic, other inclusion/exclusion criteria may also be applied. Ideally, these criteria should be pre-specified as much as possible. If not pre-specified, this deviation from the planned protocol should be reported. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5h1d8","text":"Following this secondary filtering by the individual experimenter, the experimental design for the remaining datasets and inclusion/exclusion choices should be reviewed and approved by a second researcher (such as a research mentor). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eckhl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6kq0h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"14j8d","text":"Since this is a critical step, feedback is important. For the 2023 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, these inclusion/exclusion decisions were reviewed by the mentor and whole cohort.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3hf8d","text":"After we ran all of the meta-analyses for the Summer 2022 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, we realized that datasets that were marked “external” in the Gemma database had sometimes been imported into Gemma in a format that was incompatible with Gemma’s analysis pipeline. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fp5l6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d02tu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7bgrh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a0ptp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":33,"offset":132}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4o1lj","text":"The analysis pipeline in Gemma typically begins with raw data extracted from public databases (e.g., Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO), https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/, (Lim et al., 2021)). After we ran all of the meta-analyses for the Summer 2022 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, we realized that datasets that were marked “external” in the Gemma database had been subjected to a slightly different analysis pipeline. These datasets lacked available raw data, and were therefore imported into Gemma from external databases as the probe- or gene-level summarized expression data for each subject as generated by the original dataset contributors.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"atf5h","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":5,"offset":438,"style":"italic"},{"length":5,"offset":629,"style":"italic"},{"length":6,"offset":836,"style":"italic"}],"key":"5oj3b","text":"This imported external data sometimes appeared to be in formats that were incompatible with Gemma’s analysis pipeline. This seemed to be particularly true for datasets generated with Agilent transcriptional profiling platforms, which, for proprietary reasons, always lacked raw expression data in the GEO database, and appeared to have summarized gene expression data per sample that was generated by an unstandardized analysis pipeline (i.e., GEO records included a variety of normalization methods and formats). For these Agilent records, we regularly found that the original units in GEO were non-standard or uninterpretable (e.g., just labeled “normalized”) or had something appearing to follow a standard Log2 expression unit format but then had units within the Gemma database that had clearly been log transformed a second time (e.g., the range of Log2 expression units in Gemma was highly restricted, such as units ranging between 2-4). ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"588739A228EF11EFBC560A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"1":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Lim N, Tesar S, Belmadani M, Poirier-Morency G, Mancarci BO, Sicherman J, Jacobson M, Leong J, Tan P, Pavlidis P","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1613606400,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1093/database/baab006","guid":"A5470EB907874D9395CD57ECA49E98A7","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"Curation of over 10 000 transcriptomic studies to enable data reuse."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"evesf","text":"Due to these irregularities, all datasets - especially "external" datasets - should be re-reviewed for evidence of irregular units at import or accidental double log2 transformation (as signaled by units with a highly restricted range - such as gene expression values only ranging from 2-4). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jo42","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c801c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Double-checking the range of gene expression values in a dataset","description":"","guid":"7FBE061D618011EF88250A58A9FEAC02","name":"#Pull out the matrix of gene expression data from the Summarized Experiment object:
ExpressionData_Filtered<-assay(SummarizedExperiment_Filtered[[1]])

#To observe the distribution of gene expression values, plot a histogram of the gene expression data:
hist(ExpressionData_Filtered)

#The range for the gene expression data can also be explored by examining the minimum and maximum values:
min(ExpressionData_Filtered)
max(ExpressionData_Filtered)","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

steps.section: Result Extraction: Differential Expression Results from Each Dataset
steps.step:
{"blocks":[{"key":"8h44f","text":"Within the joined file containing the differential expression results for a dataset, rows that lack unambiguous gene symbol annotation (including  “”, “null”, '\\|' in the gene symbol) need to be counted and excluded. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h24i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1iov6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8bstc","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bkqju","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"R Function: Remove rows of data that have missing or ambiguous Entrez ID gene annotation","description":"","guid":"4BA873086BC111EF89A50A58A9FEAC02","name":"FilteringDEResults_GoodAnnotation<-function(TempResultsJoined){
  
  print("# of rows in results")
  print(nrow(TempResultsJoined))
  
  print("# of rows with missing NCBI annotation:")
  print(sum(TempResultsJoined$NCBIid==""|TempResultsJoined$NCBIid=="null"))
  
  print("# of rows with NA NCBI annotation:")
  print(sum(is.na(TempResultsJoined$NCBIid)))
  
  print("# of rows with missing Gene Symbol annotation:")
  print(sum(TempResultsJoined$GeneSymbol==""|TempResultsJoined$GeneSymbol=="null"))
  
  print("# of rows mapped to multiple NCBI_IDs:")
  print(length(grep('\\|', TempResultsJoined$NCBIid)))
  
  print("# of rows mapped to multiple Gene Symbols:")
  print(length(grep('\\|', TempResultsJoined$GeneSymbol)))
  
  #I only want the subset of data which contains rows that do not contain an NCBI EntrezID of ""
  TempResultsJoined_NoNA<-TempResultsJoined[(TempResultsJoined$NCBIid==""|TempResultsJoined$NCBIid=="null")==FALSE & is.na(TempResultsJoined$NCBIid)==FALSE,]
  
  if(length(grep('\\|', TempResultsJoined_NoNA$NCBIid))==0){
    TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped<<-TempResultsJoined_NoNA
  }else{
    #I only want rows annotated with a single Gene Symbol (no pipe):
    TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped<<-TempResultsJoined_NoNA[-(grep('\\|', TempResultsJoined_NoNA$NCBIid)),]
  }
  
  print("# of rows with good annotation")
  print(nrow(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped))
  
  #For record keeping (sometimes useful for troubleshooting later)
  write.csv(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped, "TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped.csv")
  
  rm(TempResultsJoined_NoNA)
  
  print("Outputted object: TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped")
}","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example Usage: Remove rows of data that have missing or ambiguous Entrez ID gene annotation","description":"","guid":"7095F4006BC111EFB5000A58A9FEAC02","name":"FilteringDEResults_GoodAnnotation(TempResultsJoined)
# [1] "# of rows with missing NCBI annotation:"
# [1] NA
# [1] "# of rows with missing Gene Symbol annotation:"
# [1] 5
# [1] "# of rows mapped to multiple NCBI_IDs:"
# [1] 0
# [1] "# of rows mapped to multiple Gene Symbols:"
# [1] 0
# [1] "# of rows with good annotation"
# [1] 16867
# [1] "Outputted object: TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped"","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

steps.section: Result Extraction: Differential Expression Results from Each Dataset
steps.step:
{"blocks":[{"key":"cd59p","text":"The specific statistical contrasts of interest (group comparisons) that are related to your research question should be identified within the differential expression results. The Log2 Fold Changes (Log2FC - i.e., group differences in log2 gene expression) and t-statistics for these statistical contrasts need to be extracted into their own matrix. The columns in these two matrices are then given descriptive names that include the dataset ids.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4t664","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ij0n","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b1jq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R Code: Extract and rename relevant Log2FC and Tstatistic columns","description":"","guid":"E35533EA6BC311EFB5000A58A9FEAC02","name":"#This code will be dataset specific
#We need to extract the Log2FC ("Coef") and T-statistic ("t.") columns for the statistical contrasts relevant to our meta-analysis and place them into their own matrix

TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChanges<-cbind(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped$Coef.interaction.stress.x.female)

TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstats<-cbind(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped$t.interaction.stress.x.female)


#Making the row names for the Log2FC and Tstat matrices the Entrez ID gene annotation:
row.names(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChanges)<-TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped$NCBIid

row.names(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstats)<-TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped$NCBIid

#Let's rename our columns to something nicer describing the effect of interest:
#Note - we later discovered that this name needs to include the dataset identifier (GSEID#) for later joining and plotting purposes

ComparisonsOfInterest<-c("GSE85136_StressEffects_InteractionWSex")

colnames(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChanges)<-ComparisonsOfInterest
colnames(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstats)<-ComparisonsOfInterest
","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"26k2a","text":"If the row (gene) meets our criteria, we use the function rma() from the metafor package to fit a random effects meta-analysis model to the Log2FC values (yi) and accompanying SV (vi).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":58,"length":5},{"style":"italic","offset":155,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":180,"length":2},{"style":"sub","offset":156,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":181,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"891at","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6ispr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1cg03","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"214po","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d6na4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"kdtg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4t9jr","text":"Due to the relatively small number of differential expression results that are available for most topics, we have chosen to use the simplest model possible for the meta-analysis (an intercept-only model) as our main outcome. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"drff","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":5,"offset":119,"style":"italic"}],"key":"a66a0","text":"The downside to this approach is an inadequate accounting for the covariance of results derived from the same dataset (e.g., a dataset with multiple drug treatments compared to a control treatment). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ecdcg","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9mmua","text":"This approach also means that we do not attempt to quantify potentially impactful sources of
heterogeneity within the subject characteristics or methodology of the studies. If there is a larger number of datasets (e.g., 4-5 datasets representing each of the potential sources of heterogeneity), it may be worth exploring models including these variables as secondary outcomes.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2qii2","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eirqn","text":"An example of a more complicated meta-analysis that was designed to include a predictor variable (sex) can be found here:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":134,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bf5d6","text":"https://github.com/hagenaue/BrainDataAlchemy/blob/main/MetaAnalysis_GemmaDatasets%20/2023_ExampleCode_FancierMetaAnalysis_Christabel.R","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"8A7E6C786ECC11EFA6C70A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/hagenaue/BrainDataAlchemy/blob/main/MetaAnalysis_GemmaDatasets%20/2023_ExampleCode_FancierMetaAnalysis_Christabel.R"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"R Function: Running a simple (intercept-only) meta-analysis on the data frame of differential expression results","description":"","guid":"F5A1845F2A8211EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"RunBasicMetaAnalysis<-function(NumberOfComparisons, CutOffForNAs, MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges, MetaAnalysis_SV){
  
  MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow<-apply(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges[,-c(1:3)], 1, function(y) sum(is.na(y)))
  
  print("Table of # of NAs per Row (Gene):")
  print(table(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow))
  
  MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta<<-MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges[MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow<CutOffForNAs,]
  MetaAnalysis_SV_ForMeta<<-MetaAnalysis_SV[MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow<CutOffForNAs,]
  
  print("MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta:")
  print(str(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta))
  
  #I'm going to make an empty matrix to store the results of my meta-analysis:
  metaOutput<-matrix(NA, nrow(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta), 6)
  
  #And then run a loop that run's a meta-analysis on the differential expression results (columns 2-10) for each gene (row):
  for(i in c(1:nrow(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta))){
    
    effect<-as.numeric(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta[i,-c(1:3)])
    var<-as.numeric(MetaAnalysis_SV_ForMeta[i,-c(1:3)])
    
    #I added a function tryCatch that double-checks that the meta-analysis function (rma) doesn't produce errors (which breaks the loop):
    skip_to_next <- FALSE
    tryCatch(TempMeta<-rma(effect, var), error = function(e) {skip_to_next <<- TRUE})
    
    if(skip_to_next){}else{
      TempMeta<-rma(effect, var)
      metaOutput[i, 1]<-TempMeta$b #gives estimate Log2FC
      metaOutput[i, 2]<-TempMeta$se #gives standard error
      metaOutput[i, 3]<-TempMeta$pval #gives pval
      metaOutput[i, 4]<-TempMeta$ci.lb #gives confidence interval lower bound
      metaOutput[i, 5]<-TempMeta$ci.ub #gives confidence interval upper bound
      metaOutput[i, 6]<-NumberOfComparisons-sum(is.na(effect))#Number of comparisons with data
      rm(TempMeta)
    }
    rm(effect, var)
  }
  
  colnames(metaOutput)<-c("Log2FC_estimate", "SE", "pval", "CI_lb", "CI_ub", "Number_Of_Comparisons")
  row.names(metaOutput)<-MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta[,3]
  
  metaOutput<<-metaOutput
  MetaAnalysis_Annotation<<-MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta[,c(1:3)]
  return(metaOutput)
  return(MetaAnalysis_Annotation)
  
  print("metaOutput:")
  print(str(metaOutput))
  
  print("Top of metaOutput:")
  print(head(metaOutput))
  
  print("Bottom of metaOutput")
  print(tail(metaOutput))
  
}","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example Usage: Running a simple (intercept-only) meta-analysis on the data frame of differential expression results","description":"","guid":"AC89C1FD5E6611EFB6440A58A9FEAC02","name":"#We can only run a meta-analysis if there are differential expression results from more than one comparison.
#Since I know that the differential expression results from the same study (dataset) are artificially correlated, I would actually prefer that there are results from more than one dataset.

#How many genes satisfy this criteria?

#This code caculates the number of NAs in each row:
MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow<-apply(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges[,-c(1:3)], 1, function(y) sum(is.na(y)))

#I'm going to make a histogram of the results because I'm curious to see how they are distributed
hist(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow)

#Or, since there are a limited number of integer answers (0-3), I could make a table of the results:
table(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow)
# 0     1     2     3 
# 11043  4823 13346   875

#Let's try running a meta-analysis using genes that were found in at least 2 sets of differential expression results
#Since there are 3 sets of differential expression results, that means that the genes that we are including need to have 1 or fewer NAs in their results
#I set this conservatively, because there are so few studies in this meta-analysis.
#2 NA is too many


#Example Usage:

NumberOfComparisons=3
CutOffForNAs=2
#I have 3 comparisons
#2 NA is too many

metaOutput<-RunBasicMetaAnalysis(NumberOfComparisons, CutOffForNAs, MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges, MetaAnalysis_SV)
#Note: this function can take a while to run, especially if you have a lot of data  
#Plug in your computer, take a break, grab some coffee...

steps.section: Applying a False Discovery Rate (FDR) Correction to the Meta-Analysis Results
Applying a False Discovery Rate (FDR) Correction to the Meta-Analysis Results
steps.step:
{"blocks":[{"key":"8v7n","text":"We correct the p-values for false discovery rate (FDR) using the the Benjamini-Hochberg method as applied by the mt.rawp2adjp() function within the multtest package.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":113,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bqeh2","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2138r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"floaa","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eodpc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"R Function: Applying an FDR correction to meta-analysis p-values","description":"","guid":"359B3BA92A8311EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"FalseDiscoveryCorrection<-function(metaOutput){
  
  tempPvalAdjMeta<-mt.rawp2adjp(metaOutput[,3], proc=c("BH"))
  
  metaPvalAdj<-tempPvalAdjMeta$adjp[order(tempPvalAdjMeta$index),]
  
  metaOutputFDR<-cbind(metaOutput, metaPvalAdj[,2])
  
  colnames(metaOutputFDR)[7]<-"FDR"
  
  metaOutputFDR<<-metaOutputFDR
  
  print("metaOutputFDR:")
  print(str(metaOutputFDR))
  
  write.csv(metaOutputFDR, "metaOutputFDR.csv")
  
  #a version of the output in order by p-value:
  metaOutputFDR_OrderbyPval<<-metaOutputFDR[order(metaOutputFDR[,3]),]
  
  #Let's write out a version of the output in order by p-value:
  write.csv(metaOutputFDR_OrderbyPval, "metaOutputFDR_orderedByPval_wHDRFData.csv")
  
  print("Do we have any genes that are statistically significant following false discovery rate correction?")
  print(sum(metaOutputFDR[,7]<0.10, na.rm=TRUE))
  
  print("What are the top results?")
  print(head(metaOutputFDR[order(metaOutputFDR[,3]),]))
  
  rm(tempPvalAdjMeta, metaPvalAdj)
  
}

If our meta-analyses do not produce any results surviving this threshold, we may consider results at a weaker threshold (FDR\u003c0.10) with the understanding that a higher percent of these results are likely to be false discovery (10%).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

running functional ontology analyses on differential expression results from brain tissue, it is particularly important to either use a tool that either considers the full ranked list of results (i.e., all significant (FDR\u003c0.05) and non-significant results) or that compares the significant results (FDR\u003c0.05) to a \"background\" of all genes contained within the results. Do not use the full genome as the \"background\" for your functional comparison. Only a subset of the genome is expressed in brain tissue - therefore, by definition, the genes included in your results are already enriched for brain functions, regardless of their relationship to your variable of interest. {"blocks":[{"key":"f62da","text":"Examine the search terms more carefully and specify the formal search syntax.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1lg2s","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7bho8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a56pk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2tgfe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"57vvt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"78rr4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6mjs7","text":"We will be conducting our dataset search using an R coding package that accesses the API (application programming interface) for the Gemma database. Gemma's API uses formal search syntax (i.e., search term construction). This syntax is not as flexible (or smart!) as a Google search, and differs in some ways from more conventional databases such as PubMed or Embase.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"54cav","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9p7s2","text":"Examine your search terms carefully to define your formal syntax:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"a1ucc","text":"Are there a variety of potential endings for any of the terms? (e.g., \"stress\" vs. \"stressful\" vs. \"stressed\" vs. \"stressing\") If so, you may be able to just include the shared component of the term with an asterisk to indicate term expansion (e.g., \"stress*\")","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"31ahu","text":"Are any of these terms likely to identify datasets that are not related to your topic? If so, you might want to rule them out with NOT, e.g., \"stress* NOT distress\")","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6h6t","text":"If you have a term that is a phrase that includes more than one word, you may need to add quotations around that phrase if the exact phrase is desired/necessary (\"chronic social defeat stress\"). ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7oorv","text":"If you need two or more words in your phrase to be present, but the exact order/spacing is not important, you can use AND (e.g., \"chronic AND social AND stress\") or you can just include the words in parentheses \"(chronic social stress)\"","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"62fev","text":"Independent search terms can be combined into a longer list using OR (e.g., \"stress* OR advers* \")","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6vpuq","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7rj9o","text":"Defining search syntax is also a critical step, and feedback is important. For the 2023 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, these terms were reviewed by the mentor.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Search syntax for Gemma's API","description":"","guid":"4F52980460A211EFAC0E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"SearchTerms\u003c-\"(dentate gyrus stress*) OR \n(hippocamp* stress*) OR \n(Ammon's Horn stress*)\"","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1kjah","text":"Note that the SearchTerms object is a single string value containing the full search term syntax (i.e., the full syntax is wrapped in quotations - \" \").","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Applying a False Discovery Rate (FDR) Correction to the Meta-Analysis Results
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"i42q","text":"False Discovery Rate Correction: Since we have run meta-analyses for thousands of genes, we correct the p-values for false discovery rate (FDR) using the the Benjamini-Hochberg method. This coding is all performed within the R environment using Rstudio.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pflq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fr7v8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c2ucl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b1gu5","text":"To properly interpret the p-values produced by our meta-analyses for each gene, we need to take into account the fact that we have run thousands of statistical tests (i.e., one statistical test for each gene for thousands of genes). Therefore, we are likely to get a large number of results that are \"significant\" using a traditional p-value threshold (alpha=0.05) just due to random chance. This is called a multiple comparisons correction or p-value adjustment. We use a type of correction called False Discovery Rate (FDR) or q-value. It is also sometimes called a \"Benjamini–Hochberg\" adjustment after its originators.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ehl43","text":"Use the function search_datasets() to determine how many transcriptional profiling datasets within the Gemma database contain your prespecified keywords. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":17,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d89bi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7suuf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"40dmn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"49bnh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Determining how many datasets in Gemma contain your search terms","description":"","guid":"00FAF7D460A211EFBC690A58A9FEAC02","name":"result <- gemma.R ::search_datasets(SearchTerms, taxon = 'mouse',limit = 1) 

print(attributes(result)$totalElements)
#[1] 111

result <- gemma.R ::search_datasets(SearchTerms, taxon = 'rat',limit = 1) 

print(attributes(result)$totalElements)
#[1] 36","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5ufsg","text":"SearchTerms is the object created by the code in step 3.5. It is a single string value containing the full search term syntax (i.e., the full syntax is wrapped in quotations - " ").","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1plf4","text":"Taxon specifies the species for the search (e.g., 'mouse' or 'rat').","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"a66c0","text":"For this purpose (counting datasets), limit is set as 1","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8cpec","text":"print(attributes(result)$total elements) shows the number of datasets found for your search - for the first example we found 111 datasets, for the second example we found 36.","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dkpb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2j9m9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fj6s1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Excluding datasets marked as "troubled"","description":"","guid":"F4677DAD60AC11EFBC690A58A9FEAC02","name":"#How many datasets are marked by Gemma as troubled?

{"blocks":[{"key":"98r7e","text":"The gene expression data, gene (row) annotation, and sample metadata for each dataset will need to be read into R. We have chosen 'se', which stands for \"summarized experiment\"","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3kmgv","text":"The third parameter specifies whether we want to filter the gene expression data to drop genes that have low variability. Gemma applies a standardized filter across all platforms (RNA-Seq/microarray) to remove genes with minimal variance. These genes are likely to suffer from severe floor effects (very low expression/unmeasurable) or may not actually be expressed at all and the measurements that we have are just noise. The filter used by Gemma is quite permissive - it only filters out data that cause problems for the analysis. There are two stages to the variance filter: ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dfv5q","text":"    Remove genes with zero variance. ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":22,"offset":177,"style":"italic"}],"key":"3qmah","text":"    Remove genes that have too many identical values. \"Too many\" is currently defined as \u003c70% distinct values, but Dr. Paul Pavlidis says that they have tweaked this over time (personal communication).","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9dnuf","text":"The fourth parameter (consolidate=\"average\") consolidates the data for probes representing the same gene.","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"80DED93660B211EFBC690A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://rdrr.io/github/PavlidisLab/Gemma-API/man/get_dataset_object.html"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"584m7","text":"Additional example code for this step can be found here:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":128,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1bemp","text":"https://github.com/hagenaue/BrainDataAlchemy/blob/main/MetaAnalysis_GemmaDatasets%20/2023_Example_ExploringADataSet_MoreDetail.R","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"9389DC8060B111EFBC690A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/hagenaue/BrainDataAlchemy/blob/main/MetaAnalysis_GemmaDatasets%20/2023_Example_ExploringADataSet_MoreDetail.R"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8n476","text":"If there is *not* a summarized experiment object for a dataset, we can make one by adapting the code in this example:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"and80","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4ud8n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8idhd","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d89ve","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Importing a dataset that is not available as a summarized experiment","description":"","guid":"C579CDF060B411EFAC0E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"#If a summarized experiment object isn't available for a dataset (in this case dataset "GSE81672"), this is the error code that you will get:

SummarizedExperiment_Filtered<-gemma.R::get_dataset_object("GSE81672", type = 'se', filter=TRUE, consolidate="average")
# Error in `dplyr::mutate()`:
#   ! Can't transform a data frame with `NA` or `""` names.
# Run `rlang::last_trace()` to see where the error occurred.


#The expression data should be able to be imported into R using a different function:

GSE85136_Expression<-gemma.R::get_dataset_expression("GSE85136", filter=TRUE)
#There isn't an option to consolidate the data representing the same gene for this version of reading in data

str(GSE85136_Expression)
#Classes ‘data.table’ and 'data.frame':	23821 obs. of  28 variables:


#Renaming the object so the downstream code doesn't break:
#Note: Some of the downstream dimensions will be different
GSE85136_Expression_Filtered<-GSE85136_Expression


#We still need the metadata for this dataset object:


GSE85136_Samples<-gemma.R::get_dataset_design("GSE85136")

str(GSE85136_Samples)
#'data.frame':	24 obs. of  4 variables:

#Double-checking that it is in the same order as the expression data.frame:
row.names(GSE85136_Samples)
# [1] "ControlMale3"   "ControlFemale2" "GFPFemale1"     "GFPMale1"       "StressFemale2"  "CREMale3"      
# [7] "StressMale1"    "CREFemale1"     "StressFemale1"  "GFPMale3"       "CREFemale2"     "GFPMale2"      
# [13] "StressFemale3"  "StressMale2"    "ControlFemale3" "ControlFemale1" "CREMale2"       "GFPFemale3"    
# [19] "ControlMale2"   "GFPFemale2"     "StressMale3"    "ControlMale1"   "CREMale1"       "CREFemale3"    

colnames(GSE85136_Expression_Filtered)
# [1] "Probe"            "GeneSymbol"       "GeneName"         "NCBIid"           "Control Male 3"   "Control Male 1"  
# [7] "Control Male 2"   "Stress Male 2"    "Stress Male 1"    "Stress Male 3"    "GFP Male 3"       "GFP Male 2"      
# [13] "GFP Male 1"       "CRE Male 3"       "CRE Male 2"       "CRE Male 1"       "Control Female 3" "Control Female 1"
# [19] "Control Female 2" "Stress Female 3"  "Stress Female 2"  "Stress Female 1"  "GFP Female 3"     "GFP Female 2"    
# [25] "GFP Female 1"     "CRE Female 3"     "CRE Female 2"     "CRE Female 1" 

#Interestingly, it is *not* in the same order, and the names don't match.
#To make a version that matches, we would need to remove spaces

ExpressionColnames_NoSpaces<- gsub(" ", "", colnames(GSE85136_Expression_Filtered)[-c(1:4)])

#What the names look like with the spaces removed:
ExpressionColnames_NoSpaces
# [1] "ControlMale3"   "ControlMale1"   "ControlMale2"   "StressMale2"    "StressMale1"    "StressMale3"   
# [7] "GFPMale3"       "GFPMale2"       "GFPMale1"       "CREMale3"       "CREMale2"       "CREMale1"      
# [13] "ControlFemale3" "ControlFemale1" "ControlFemale2" "StressFemale3"  "StressFemale2"  "StressFemale1" 
# [19] "GFPFemale3"     "GFPFemale2"     "GFPFemale1"     "CREFemale3"     "CREFemale2"     "CREFemale1"  

#To get the metadata in the same order, we could use join or merge:

#To do this, we need to load the plyr package:
library(plyr)

#We also need to make the gene expression data column names it's own object (a data frame) with a column name ("x"):  
ExpressionColnames_NoSpaces_toJoin<-data.frame(x=ExpressionColnames_NoSpaces)

#We then need to make a data frame for the metadata what has a column of names that is also named "x":
GSE85136_Samples_toJoin<-data.frame(x=row.names(GSE85136_Samples), GSE85136_Samples)

#Then we can join the metadata to the gene expression data column names dataframe using type="left". That will make it so that the metadata is now in the same order as the gene expression data columns.
GSE85136_Samples_toJoin_inOrder<-join(ExpressionColnames_NoSpaces_toJoin, GSE85136_Samples_toJoin, by="x", type="left")

#We should confirm that the metadata is now in the same order as the gene expression data columns:
GSE85136_Samples_toJoin_inOrder$x
# [1] "ControlMale3"   "ControlMale1"   "ControlMale2"   "StressMale2"    "StressMale1"    "StressMale3"   
# [7] "GFPMale3"       "GFPMale2"       "GFPMale1"       "CREMale3"       "CREMale2"       "CREMale1"      
# [13] "ControlFemale3" "ControlFemale1" "ControlFemale2" "StressFemale3"  "StressFemale2"  "StressFemale1" 
# [19] "GFPFemale3"     "GFPFemale2"     "GFPFemale1"     "CREFemale3"     "CREFemale2"     "CREFemale1"   


#Now we can make a summarized experiment object using the gene expression data and the metadata:
GSE85136_SummarizedExperiment<-SummarizedExperiment(assays=list(counts=GSE85136_Expression_Filtered[,-c(1:4)]), colData=GSE85136_Samples_toJoin_inOrder, rowData=GSE85136_Expression_Filtered[,c(1:4)])

GSE81672_LibrarySize<-read.csv("GSE81672_LibrarySize.csv", header=TRUE, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

#The library size information is annotated with sample information using GSM number. 
head(GSE81672_LibrarySize)
# ExternalID X..Aligned M.Aligned X..Dups X..GC M.Seqs
# 1 GSM2166101     85.00%      20.1                   NA
# 2 GSM2166102     86.10%      33.4                   NA

#As far as I can tell, this identifier is not in the Summarized experiment object

As far as I can tell, this identifier is not in the Summarized experiment object, so we need to read in the experimental design info from the Gemma website, which contains GSM#. To do this, we need to go to the Experimental Design tab for the dataset within Gemma and click on \"Show Details\".","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}","mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Protocol_AccessExperimentalDesign.jpg","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rcsgcd2jf.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rir4cd2jf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rir3cd2jf.webp","width":550}},"6":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"BFFAED9260C311EFA2300A58A9FEAC02","height":404,"id":500206,"is_video":false,"legend":"{"blocks":[{"key":"4pocj","text":"Within the Experimental Design details, click on \"download design file\". This will download a tab-delimited text file which will be named after the dataset (e.g., \"13458_GSE81672_expdesign.data.txt\"). Save it in the working directory for your project.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}","mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Protocol_DownloadExperimentDesignDetails.jpg","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rcsicd2jf.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rirqcd2jf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rirpcd2jf.webp","width":550}},"7":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Reading in the experimental design file containing the GSM#s for Samples","description":"","guid":"8AA9D2FF60C411EF96DE0A58A9FEAC02","name":"#To read in the experimental design file that contains the GSM#s for the samples:

GSE81672_expdesign<-read.delim("13458_GSE81672_expdesign.data.txt", sep="\t", comment.char="#", header=TRUE, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)


#This column has the GSM #
GSE81672_expdesign$ExternalID
# [1] "GSM2166189" "GSM2166195" "GSM2166180"

#This column includes the Name... and a bunch of other stuff:
GSE81672_expdesign$Bioassay
# [1] "GSE81672_Biomat_64___BioAssayId=450411Name=Sample102.NAC_susceptible_ketamine_non_responder"  
# [2] "GSE81672_Biomat_58___BioAssayId=450412Name=Sample108.HIP_susceptible_saline"
#...","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"8":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Reformatting the experimental design sample ids to match the Summarized Experiment","description":"","guid":"1C5E2B7F60C511EFA2300A58A9FEAC02","name":"#This column includes the Name... and a bunch of other stuff:
GSE81672_expdesign$Bioassay
# [1] "GSE81672_Biomat_64___BioAssayId=450411Name=Sample102.NAC_susceptible_ketamine_non_responder"  
# [2] "GSE81672_Biomat_58___BioAssayId=450412Name=Sample108.HIP_susceptible_saline"
#...

#This code splits these long names up at the "Name=" and then combines things back into a matrix again
temp<-do.call(rbind.data.frame, strsplit(GSE81672_expdesign$Bioassay, "Name="))

#This adds the name information to the expdesign matrix:
GSE81672_expdesign$SampleName<-temp[,2]
GSE81672_expdesign$SampleName

#For this dataset, The formatting is still a little different from the Summarized Experiment object, e.g.
GSE81672_expdesign$SampleName[1]
#"Sample102.NAC_susceptible_ketamine_non_responder"

row.names(colData(SummarizedExperiment_Filtered[[1]]))[1]
#"Sample 18: AMY_resilient_saline"
#One version uses a ., the other uses a ": "

#the ": " version is straight off of Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO), so I'm going to assume that for some reason Gemma doesn't like : in the design data.frame

#This is likely to be a dataset specific issue - I'm not sure how to generalize this code.
#For many datasets, things may be fine at this point.

#So we essentially need a find and replace - in R, these are often done with sub() or gsub()
#https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/sub-and-gsub-function-r
#https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/grep

#this is a little funky, because we're not replacing simple alphanumeric characters, but punctuation that also has a meaning for coding
temp<-gsub("[.]", ": ", GSE81672_expdesign$SampleName)

#But it turns out that the names also differ because of an extra space. 
#To take care of this we just removed all spaces from both vectors because it is easier:

GSE81672_expdesign$SampleName_toJoin<-gsub(" ", "", temp)

SampleName_toJoin<-gsub(" ", "", row.names(colData(SummarizedExperiment_Filtered[[1]])))","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"9":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Adding library size info to the Summarized Experiment object","description":"","guid":"7A0EE3A760C511EFA2300A58A9FEAC02","name":"#We can't just add library size as a column to experimental design because the samples aren't in the same order
#We have to use a "join" or "merge" function to align them instead

#To join the design matrix with the library size, we need to have two data.frames that have columns that have the same name:
str(GSE81672_LibrarySize)

#In this data.frame, the GSM# is called Sample.Name, whereas in the exp. design data.frame it is called ExternalID, so I will rename it ExternalID:
colnames(GSE81672_LibrarySize)[1]<-"ExternalID"

#Now we can join by these columns (the function "merge" also works for this):
GSE81672_expdesign_wLibrarySize<-join(GSE81672_expdesign, GSE81672_LibrarySize, by="ExternalID", type="left")


#Now we have to add this information into the Summarized Experiment object
#Which also has a different sample order
#I'm going to grab that sample order information and name it after the column with Sample Names in the experimental design object

SamplesOrderedLikeSummarizedExperiment<-data.frame(SampleName_toJoin=SampleName_toJoin)
                                
GSE81672_expdesign_wLibrarySize_Ordered<-join(SamplesOrderedLikeSummarizedExperiment, GSE81672_expdesign_wLibrarySize, by="SampleName_toJoin", type="left")                   


#Double checking that things are actually in the same order
cbind(row.names(colData(SummarizedExperiment_Filtered[[1]])), GSE81672_expdesign_wLibrarySize_Ordered$SampleName_toJoin)

#Then I can finally add library size to the Summarized Experiment object:
colData(SummarizedExperiment_Filtered[[1]])$LibrarySize<-GSE81672_expdesign_wLibrarySize_Ordered$M.Aligned","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}
